definition: to seek an audience with higher-ups (esp. government officials) to petition for sth
on top/upon/above/upper/previous/first (of multiple parts)/to climb/to get onto/to go up/to attend (class or university)
see 上聲|上声[shang3 sheng1]
to visit/to call on/to seek/to inquire/to investigate

sentences.english: I say 99 percent of repeat petitioners are mentally ill.
sentences.chinese: 我敢说99%的上访专业户精神有问题。

sentences.english: Xu told the protestors that the relocation was still in the planning stages.
sentences.chinese: 徐省长告诉上访者说该搬迁方案尚在计划阶段。

sentences.english: Beijing suburb farmers' appealing to the higher authorities for help focus losing land problems.
sentences.chinese: 失地问题已成为京郊农民上访的主流。

sentences.english: The most dogged petitioners are often classified as crazy.
sentences.chinese: 大部分上访钉子户都是精神病。

sentences.english: The petitioning system has long provided an outlet for rural grievances.
sentences.chinese: 长期以来，上访制度为农村积怨提供了一个出口。

sentences.english: It was in the street, he accidentally received a petition to Beijing to complain to the case.
sentences.chinese: 那是他在街上无意中受理的一个进京上访告状案。

sentences.english: Fellow petitioners collect their body parts and call for the ouster of the Communist Party.
sentences.chinese: 同是上访的人搜集了两位的残肢，喊着政党下台。

definition: complaint letter/petition letter/see also 上訪|上访[shang4 fang3]
officials shield one another (idiom); a cover-up
to tell on sb/to complain (to a teacher, a superior etc)/to bring a lawsuit
to appeal for justice/to demand redress for a grievance
to file a complaint/to appeal (to an authority, a higher court of justice etc)/complaint/appeal
to handle a case
mass incident (PRC term for incidents of social unrest, including rioting, melees and petition campaigns)
to bend the law in order to favor one's relatives or associates (idiom)
high court
a misjudged legal case/a miscarriage (of justice)
to circumvent the law
to seize and subject to public criticism (form of persecution during the Cultural Revolution)

(neologism c. 2013) organized disruption of healthcare facilities or verbal and physical abuse of medical staff, by an aggrieved patient or proxies such as family members or hired thugs, typically aimed at obtaining compensation
reeducation through labor
judge (in court)
to demand payment/to collect overdue payment
